newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan party extends welcome to Chinese dissident.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan party extends welcome to Chinese dissident.

text.p: Taiwan's ruling Nationalist Party (Kuomintang) said on Tuesday that it would welcome Chinese dissident Wang Xizhe into the party if he voices support for Taiwan's Republic of China government.

"The position of the Nationalist Party is that we welcome those who identify themselves with the ideas of the Republic of China and the Nationalist Party," party deputy secretary-general Hansen Chien said on state-funded television.
Wang, speaking in public for the first time since fleeing to the United States, said on Monday in Oakland, California, that he would apply to join the Kuomintang, or KMT.
"I hope the KMT leadership will consider my membership application seriously," he said.
Wang said he hoped someday to join a KMT delegation in negotiations with Beijing on the reunification of China and Taiwan.
Wang could apply to the KMT's department of overseas affairs to join the party, Chien said.
Taiwan and China have been diplomatic rivals since the Chinese civil war ended in 1949 with Mao Zedong's Communists driving Chiang Kai-shek and his Nationalists to Taiwan.
Beijing now regards Taiwan as a renegade province while Taipei, though maintaining an official policy of reunification, claims to be an independent political entity.

Wang fled his home in China's Guangdong province earlier this month, just days after Chinese authorities arrested pro-democracy activist Liu Xiaobo and ordered him to serve three years in a labour camp.
Wang went first to Hong Kong and then flew via Europe to the San Francisco area last week.

Wang, 46, one of China's leading dissidents, said through an interpreter in Oakland that he would not apply for political asylum in the United States until authorities in Taiwan give him a definite answer on his party application.
Taiwan's top authority on policies toward mainland China, the Mainland Affairs Council, said Wang was also eligible to immigrate to Taiwan.

"According to current regulations, he can apply to come and stay in Taiwan," Liu Teh-hsun, director of the council's legal affairs department, said on state-owned radio, citing a Taiwan policy allowing mainland Chinese who contribute to democracy to apply to immigrate.

Wang's activism dates from 1974 when he co-authored an attack in Guangdong on the radical 1966-76 Cultural Revolution. He took part in the 1979 Democracy Wall movement in Beijing and produced his own dissident newsletters.
He was twice imprisoned, spending a total of 17 years in jail and labour camps. He was released on parole in 1993.
